instruction: What spectral feature processing methods were used in the classification model for peatland restoration monitoring?
Output: The spectral feature processing methods used in the classification model for peatland restoration monitoring included cloud-free, atmosphere-corrected Sentinel 2 data and GetMapping aerial photography data.

instruction: What metric was chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the classification model for peatland restoration monitoring, and how far can this metric go in predicting land covers?
Output: The metric chosen to evaluate the accuracy of the classification model for peatland restoration monitoring was overall accuracy. This metric can provide a general assessment of how well the model predicts different land covers.

instruction: What were the different types of satellite data used to assess the accuracy of the classification model for peatland restoration monitoring in northern Scotland?
Output:
The different types of satellite data used to assess the accuracy of the classification model for peatland restoration monitoring in northern Scotland were:

1. Sentinel-2 satellite data: This data was used to create one version of the model. It was compared against sub-metre resolution aerial imagery to evaluate the accuracy obtainable from both sources.

2. Sub-metre resolution aerial imagery from GetMapping: This data was used to create another version of the model. It was compared against Sentinel-2 satellite data to assess the accuracy of prediction.

Additionally, in a further study, multiple years of satellite data (2015-2021) were used, including Sentinel-1 SAR imagery, to confirm the findings obtained with a single climatically average year and to examine the efficacy of different restoration methods.

instruction: Can the classification model based on remote sensing data using the Sentinel-2 spectrum outperform traditional aerial imagery-based models in predicting post-restoration trajectories of peatland restoration areas in northern Scotland?
Output: Yes, the classification model based on remote sensing data using the Sentinel-2 spectrum greatly outperformed traditional aerial imagery-based models in predicting post-restoration trajectories of peatland restoration areas in northern Scotland.
